importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Fighting between the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) began in April 2023, leading to the closure of Khartoum international airport and widespread destruction of infrastructure.
The Khartoum airport was scheduled to reopen just one day before the drone attacks, highlighting the precarious nature of stability and recovery in post-conflict Sudan.
The drone attacks occurred on 2025-10-21, directly threatening the reopening of the airport and undermining ongoing reconstruction efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: In the past seven days, drone attacks have occurred multiple times in Khartoum, signaling a persistent threat to civilian and military infrastructure despite the army's recapture of the capital.

keyTakeAways: Khartoum international airport, which had been closed for over two years due to conflict damage, was targeted by a drone attack just one day before its scheduled reopening.
The attacks, reported to include suicide drones, occurred near the airport between 4am and 6am on 2025-10-21, with over eight blasts reported by Sudanese media.
The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a paramilitary group, is blamed for the attacks, with security sources and witnesses indicating the use of drones to target military and civilian infrastructure.
The Sudan Civil Aviation Authority announced the gradual resumption of domestic flights, but the drone attacks have disrupted this progress and raised concerns about safety.
The RSF has continued attacks on military bases and civilian infrastructure, especially in the west, including a prior attack on army bases in northwest Khartoum.
The broader conflict has caused widespread displacement, with nearly 12 million people displaced and tens of thousands killed, and has created the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises.
The RSF’s control over el-Fasher in Darfur remains a key geopolitical concern, as its capture would give them control over much of southern Sudan and expand their reach.
The United Nations has issued warnings about potential large-scale ethnically driven attacks in Darfur if the RSF succeeds in capturing el-Fasher.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A series of drone attacks, including suicide drones, targeted Khartoum international airport and surrounding areas in Sudan just one day before its long-awaited reopening. The attacks, blamed on the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF), occurred between 4am and 6am on 2025-10-21 and involved over eight blasts, with witnesses reporting explosions and smoke rising from the airport perimeter. The Sudan Civil Aviation Authority had previously announced plans to resume domestic flights, but the drone attacks have disrupted this progress. The RSF has continued launching attacks on military and civilian infrastructure, including army bases in northwest Khartoum, indicating a persistent threat even after the Sudanese army regained control of Khartoum in early 2025. The broader conflict has led to widespread displacement, with nearly 12 million people displaced and tens of thousands killed, and the RSF’s siege of el-Fasher in Darfur raises fears of large-scale ethnic violence. The United Nations has issued warnings about the potential for further atrocities, underscoring the humanitarian crisis and global relevance of the ongoing war in Sudan.
title: Drone attack in Sudan threatens Khartoum airport’s reopening: Reports
